results.title: Interviews
results.creator_credit: Harris Watts, Mike Crisp and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “On camera: the BBC video production course”.
Deals with interview techniques both inside and outside the studio. Shows how to shoot an interview using either one or two cameras. Diagrams are used to relate camera position, interviewer and guest to what appears on the scree. The importance of cutaways, shot sizes and the positioning of props are also covered.

results.title: Editing
results.creator_credit: Harris Watts, Mike Crisp and British Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “On camera: the BBC video production course”.
Two versions of an item about a factory that has introduced morning exercises for its workers. Shows how the same material can be edited in different ways to change the shape of the story. There is also a demonstration of how interviews can be edited to greatest advantage and how shots can be juxtaposed to make the best use of materials.

results.title: Camera
results.creator_credit: Harris Watts, Mike Crisp and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “On camera: the BBC video production course”.
Consist of four parts: 1. The “Camera and the eye”. Shows the difficulties faced by the camera lens as compared by the eye and notes the advantages of the camera. 2. “Lenses and apertures”. Explains focal length, angle of view, depth of field, aperture openings, the times 2 extender and the gain switch. 3. “Short sizes and camera moves”. Explains basic terminology - such as pan, tilt, depress, track and zoom. 4. “Crossing the line” Shows how to mantain continuity of direction to avoid confusing the viewer.

results.title: Age of metals: can it last?
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
Episode 7 from the interesting series “Out of the fiery furnace” discusses whether societies accept the environmental penalties of increased metal mining? Are there enough metals left on earth for all who want them? What will we do for energy if the rest of the world is to be carried forward into the Age of Metals? New methods of exploration and detection are shown, including earth-imaging satellites.

results.title: From alchemy to the atom
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
Episode six from “Out of the Fiery Furnace.” Scientists of the 20th century discover how to to transform matter not into gold but into energy. European scientists work towards an understanding of atoms and the energy they release.

results.title: Into the machine age
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
The ever expanding American iron and steel industry spawns the railroads that help to reunify a country riven by civil war. In the aftermath of the Chicago fire on 1871, the industry creates the steel-framed skycraper. The discovery of vast reserves of oil, and the advent of mass production, mark the last quarter of the nineteenth century.

results.title: Revolution of necessity
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
The discovery of how to turn coke into fuel launches the Industrial Revolution. The need for better pumps in the mines eventually leads to the steam engine, which together with the railway transforms society. Bessemer’s converter gives the world cheap steel.

results.title: Shining conquests
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Out of the fiery furnace”.
EPISODE 3 OF OUT OF THE FIERY FURNACE. The flood of wealth from precious metals helps finance the Renaissance, and a great wave of colonization and exploration. In a later century came the “democratic” gold rushes in America and Australia, followed by capital intensive deep-lead mining. The social implications are discussed.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Christopher McCullough, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
